text: [music playing]

DAN LASKO: 13 Years ago, I
lost my left leg below the knee
due to an IED ambush.

The armored vehicle I was
in just traveled over two
improvised exploding devices.

That's when my left leg
was pretty much shredded.

And it wasn't until I got to
Bethesda National Naval Medical

Center, when the
doctor said, hey,

you're going to be wearing
a prosthetic device.

It was difficult
at first, you know,

trying to get used
to having one limb

and then wearing prosthetics,
getting used to taking it off,
putting it back on.

- We developed this first
state-of-the-art clip-on unit

onto a standard
prosthetic leg to meet

an unmet clinical
need for people like
Dan and other active amputees.

DAN LASKO: I already have
my fellow wounded warriors

asking me about this
device and how to get one.

DAN LASKO: And it feels
like I'm back to normal.

I can feel the propulsion when
I'm kicking my left leg again.
You know, I have two young boys.
Ben is two.
Lucas is six.

And these two kids
love the water.

This is a life changer
for them as well

when I can get in
the pool with them
and teach them how to swim.

There's absolutely no reason why
any disability should hold you
back from what you want to do.
